Line: I've been so bored since we moved here, I've found myself drinking a glass of wine every day. I know doctors say you should drink a glass and a half, but I just can't drink that much.

Line: It's up to you, Homer. Whatever you decide, that's what we'll do.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I think owning the Denver Broncos is pretty good.

Line: Well explain to me why it isn't.

Line: Weren't there three Indians last year?

Line: No, I don't.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, please, you're hurting my arm!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Night vision goggles? A bathroom scale from a Soviet sub? A suede briefcase-case? Oh, anyone who needs this kind of status symbol must have some terrible emotional problems...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, of all the crazy ideas you've had, this one ranks somewhere in the middle. You're thirty-eight years old, you don't know how to box and you haven't gotten any exercise since grade school. Before you even consider this, I insist you consult a doctor.

Speaker: Marge
Line: A competent doctor!

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's what we get for living in a state founded by circus freaks.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, why are they saying you're going to fight Drederick Tatum?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Have you lost your mind?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: But you'll get killed!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Moe, I'm so glad I found you. Please promise me you won't let Homer get hurt.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Listen to me. The instant that Homer's in any kind of danger, I want you to throw in this towel and stop the fight.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Thank you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Celebrities at ringside tonight: star of the "McBain" action films and featured player in the Hollywood prostitution scandal, Rainier Wolfcastle; TV anchorman and Springfield institution, Mr. Kent Brockman.

Speaker: Marge
Line: What? What?! What am I missing? What?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer! Homer, he's not going to get tired! You've got to hit him back! Hit him back!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Somebody stop the fight! Where's the doctor?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Homie, are you okay?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, that's all right. We'll just wait until everyone else leaves.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Thank you, Moe. I know you gave up your dreams for Homer.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I feel sorry for everyone who's cooped up inside watching the seventh game of the World Series!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Next to spring and winter, fall is my absolute favorite season. Just look at all this beautiful foilage.

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's what I said, foilage . It doesn't take a nucular scientist to pronounce foilage.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I can honestly say that was the most fun I've ever had. The mill, the history, all that gorgeous foliage.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I can't excape Lisa, our little walking libary!

Speaker: Marge
Line: No! What if he's crazy?

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're not picking him up!

Speaker: Marge
Line: There's not enough room!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I just don't think it's a good idea.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Careful of the apple pie on the seat.

Line: Grampa, are you sitting on the pie?

Line: He sexually harassed me.

Line: Yay, Mom! All right, Mom!

Line: I think we heard enough about Larry Burns for one evening.

Speaker: Marge
Line: What are you doing in the basement? It's like you're hiding out down here.

Line: And what's that hitchhiker doing here? Is every drifter we meet going to move in with us?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh. Yeah. Thank you.

Line: Can't we just go upstairs?

Line: Kidnapped?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know how I feel about hoaxes!

Line: I want you to take Larry back to Mr. Burns right now, before you get in a lot of trouble.

Speaker: Marge
Line: No excuses! Just do it!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ohhh! Give yourself up, Homie!

Line: And where is all that liquor coming from?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Honey, we don't need to drive 400 miles to clean animals. You can stay right here and give the dog a bath. Or trim the cat's nails.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You've already used up your birthday and Christmas presents on that peach tree we got you. And you hardly ever play with that anymore.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, all right, we'll go.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Now, the cat needs his medication every morning --

Speaker: Marge
Line: And the furnace has been giving off a lot of carbon monoxide, so keep the window o--

Speaker: Marge
Line: Uh, you know, I think I'll take Maggie with us.

Speaker: Marge
Line: And if anything happens, just use your best judgm... Just do what I would do.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I've got rocks that need washing at home.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Lisa, I know it's frustrating. But we made a commitment and we have to see it through, no matter how unpleasant.

Speaker: Marge
Line: "Maison Derriere"?! I can't believe there's a place like that in our wholesome little town. Homer, did you know it was a burlesque house when you sent Bart to work there?

Line: What were you thinking, sending Bart to such an awful place?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I have a favor to ask: please shut this place down and move away from Springfield.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Springfield doesn't want places like this!

Line: Oh? I've lived in this town for 37 years.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm third generation.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Get out of my town!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Is that so? Well, sleazy entertainment and raunchy jokes will never be as popular as sobriety and self-denial!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You're about to learn the two most dangerous words in the English language are Marge Simpson!

Line: It's the light pink '87 wagon.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm here to share my moral outrage, but this time it's not about that giant, inflatable Dos Equis bottle. It's about a certain house in our town...

Line: No. It's a House of Ill Fame... a House of Loose Ethics...

Line: The house is perfectly fine!

Line: Oh, geez -- It's what's inside the house that's disgraceful -- drinking, gambling, and debauchery! It's right under our noses -- a secret house of burlesque!

Line: I rest my case.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Here I come, everybody!

Speaker: Marge
Line: No, I had to go rent the bulldozer.

Line: What about the sleaze and the depravity?!

Line: Oh, can you sing it again?

Line: Well, I also have a song to sing!

Line: Don't make up your mind until you hear both songs! Morals and ethics and carnal forbearance...

Line: Uh... sorry.

Line: I'm so sorry. How can I ever make this up to you?

Line: So, Twiggy, I hear you and your husband Woody just had a baby. What did you name him?

Line: Is it really necessary to watch TV while we're eating? We're getting food all over.

Line: You're talking about a trough! We're not going to eat from a trough! And another thing -- it's only 5:15. Why are you in your underwear?

Line: At least let's have a civilized conversation, shall we? Lisa, how was school?

Line: School. School.

Line: I know it's not! I'm going into the dining room to have a conversation. Anyone who wants to join me is welcome.

Line: Hello Marge. How's the family? I don't want to talk about it. Mind your own business.

Line: Homer, is this the way you pictured married life?

Line: Well, I pictured cocktail parties and candle-lit dinners. I pictured napkins... Homer, I want to throw a dinner party.

Line: I don't care if the sink shoots sludge, we're having a party.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's just not a dinner party without a melon baller. And we'll need a citrus zester... a ravioli crimper... Ooh, an oyster mallet! "Made in U.S.A."? Eh, no thank you!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well... maybe we could use it once and then return it.

Line: Bart, company's coming. Go put doilies under the coasters. Hurry! Hurry!

Line: Lisa, quick. Screw these back on.

Line: Oh, good. That will give me time to add another coat of glaze to the ham.

Line: Are you ready?

Line: The only thing I asked you to do for this party was put on clothes. And you didn't do it.

Line: And now it's too late -- they're here. Bart, greet our guests and take their coats.

Line: So, did anyone see that new Woodsy Allen movie?

Line: Lisa! Why don't you come sing for us!

Line: I feel terrible. The Van Houtens split up at our party.

Line: I shouldn't have served those North Korean fortune cookies. They were so insulting: "You are a coward." No one likes to hear that after a nice meal.

Line: You know who the real victim is in all this? Milhouse.

Line: I must say, Luann, you're really handling this splendidly.

Line: Actually, Luann, I don't really know anything about yo--

Line: You said you'd do it as a favor to me.

Line: Homie, I appreciate this, but I'd really like to get some sleep.

Line: Edmondo, don't you think you're taking a lot off -- Ah!... Homer! What are you doing?!

Line: None! They would have more sense than that.

Line: Homer, I don't need you around me 24 hours a day. I'm a grown woman -- I can take care of myself. Now, will you please just go away!

Line: Only three cavities, Bart. Your best check-up ever. I'm going to make you my specialty -- butterscotch chicken.

Line: Why? Am I pregnant?

Line: Oh, Homie. I know you love me. We don't need to get married again.

Line: I will. Oh Homie, of course I will.

Line: It's the most perfect wedding I could ever ask for. You even got a hip rock 'n' roll combo.

Line: What a wonderful evening! A magical way for two people to renew their love.

Line: An automatic dialer? Is that legal? I don't want you getting arrested, Homer...

Line: But you're going to annoy thousands of people just to make a few measly dollars. It's nothing but panhandling!

Line: Well, most women will tell you that you're a fool to think you can change a man... but those women are quitters!

Line: When I first met your father, he was loud, crude, and piggish. But I worked hard on him, and now he's a whole new person!

Line: He's a whole new person, Lisa!

Line: Ooh, a Rubik's Cube. Let's all work it together.

Line: Now I remember why I put

Line: Dear God, this is Marge Simpson. If you stop this hurricane and save our family, we will be forever grateful and recommend you to all our friends. So if you could find it in your infinite wisdom to...

Line: I started making some calls last night, and before I knew it, practically all of Springfield was offering to help.

Line: Homer!

Line: Well, don't look at me... just because I'm holding a pair of scissors. Scissors which I need... to uh... to gussy-up these curtains.

Line: Well, I just felt like filling the house with the rich, satisfying smell of tobacco.

Line: No, Homie, wait!

Line: All right, I was trying to keep it from you, but I had a good reason. Every time you go to that cook-off, you get drunk as a poet on payday. Remember last year?

Line: Thank you for your concern, Helen. Homer isn't drinking today.

Line: It looks so complicated... Do you know how?

Line: Woo-woo!

Line: You promised you wouldn't drink!

Line: Has anyone seen Homer?

Speaker: Marge
Line: No beer, huh? I guess I know what a promise from Homer J. Simpson is worth.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Your father decided he'd rather come home in a taxi. Or a police car.

Line: I'm "cranky" because my husband got drunk and humiliated me in front of the entire town. You broke your promise, Homer.

Line: Don't "soul mate" me!

Line: Oh, Homer, thank goodness you're safe!

Line: I woke up and you weren't there, and I was so worried...

Line: Well, I was sure you'd be on foot, because you always say public transportation is for losers. And I was sure you'd head west, because Springfield slopes down that way. And then I saw the lighthouse, and I remembered how you love blinking lights... like the one on the waffle iron...

Line: Yeah.

Line: I-Is this about that pen that I took from the Post Office? I-I swear I didn't know I put it in my purse. Then I was going to bring it back, but the dog chewed it up and that just made things worse...

Line: Oh. Come. Come in.

Line: Homer, please! I try to be supportive, but this has gone too far. Please just let it be.

Line: Oh Homie! Homie, I'm so sorry I doubted you!

Line: Well, you said you'd bring them peace and love and it looks like you did it. I'm proud of you, Homie.

Line: I'm not wild about these high-risk ventures. They sound a little risky.

Line: I guess I'm just not comfortable with the whole idea of "investing"...

Line: All right, Helen, if I'm not wanted, I'll leave.

Line: ...and then they gave me back my 500 dollar investment and kicked me out of the club.

Line: Well, maybe it's all for the best...

Line: It would be nice to beat those women at their own game. Maybe I should look into a franchise.

Line: Well, we're trying to, but you're blocking our way.

Line: Uh... oh...

Line: Look at them. They've jumped on the one franchise I might possibly have considered thinking about becoming interested in. I'm not cut out for the world of business.

Line: Mmm... hmm... That's not bad.

Line: Your franchise, how much?

Line: I'll take it!

Line: When can I start? What's my territory?

Line: Welcome to Pretzel Wagon. May I take your order?

Line: Thank you.

Line: Excuse me. I had this spot first.

Line: Well, I guess Macy's and Gimbel's learned to live side by side.

Line: Very well. There must be dozens of great locations in this town. Don't you worry about me.

Line: You see? A little persistence and patience paid off. That'll be 300 dollars.

Line: I should've said "limit -- one per customer."

Line: "Hang in there, baby." You said it, kitty. Copyright 1968? Hmm. Determined or not, that cat must be long dead. That's kind of a downer.

Line: Here you go -- free Pretzel Wagon pretzels for everyone! One bite and you'll be hooked!

Line: Oh, no! No! Don't do that! You're supposed to be tasting them!

Line: I was wrong to have a dream. Wrong as usual. I mean, if you're nothing special, why kid yourself?

Line: Listen to your mother, kids: aim low. Aim so low, no one will even care if you succeed.

Line: Dinner's in the oven. If you want some butter, it's under my face.

Line: Hello? Uh, no, Pretzel Wagon's no longer -- Three hundred pretzels?! Wait, wait, let me get this down. Mmm... Mmm... Meatpackers Union Hall... Batavia, New York... I'll send them right out! Homer, Homie, wake up! Wake up, I'm back in business!

Line: Are you sure the children will get enough nutrition from these pretzels?

Line: Oh my God, what happened to your fingers?!

Line: Well, here I am -- 11905 Dead Weasel Road, but I don't see any apartment building, I just --

Line: Hey, what's going on?

Line: Oh, oh, you have to push in as you turn.

Line: Yeah, that's it.

Line: Who are you?

Line: What are you talking about?

Line: Homer, did you tell the Mafia they could eliminate my competitors with savage beatings and attempted murder?

Line: Oh, it just sickens me. How could you do this to someone you love?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Homer, I know you were trying to shield me from failure, but this is my business, and the Mafia's not getting one cent of my money!

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're going to do what we do every day. We're going to make pretzels.

Line: There, that's the last one.

Line: The answer is no.

Line: Homie, maybe we should go inside.

Line: Oh, I don't hate you for failing. I love you for trying.

Line: Oh, it's just a mob war. Go back to sleep, Honey.

Line: Don't worry, kids. This is a national park. We can have lots of fun.

Line: Okay, but when you start getting apple-cheeked, it's time to come in.

Line: Bart? Lisa?

Line: All right... but don't be shocked.

Line: Homie, I'm losing my hair.

Line: I was just with Dr. Hibbert. He said I was under a lot of stress and should get some help.

Line: Well... I was thinking we could hire a nanny to help me out.

Line: Homie, please, I never ask for much, but this is something I really need.

Line: Pleased to meet you.

Line: Homer, if you're going to do this to every applicant, we're never going to find one.

Line: I'm sorry, young man, you're not what we're looking for.

Line: I heard that!

Line: I guess we're not going to find anyone.

Line: That's Carl.

Line: Well, I'd like to hear your suggestions.

Line: Homer!

Line: Well that's nice, kids, but I don't know where we're going to find anyone like that.

Line: No.

Line: Shary Bobbins, you're just what we're looking for.

Line: My, she seems too good to be true.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, I can see myself!

Line: That Shary Bobbins is a miracle worker. The kids love her, the house is spotless -- and my hair's grown back. It's so full and thick it can support a beach umbrella!

Line: Ooooh.

Line: Oh, thank you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Thank you for everything.

Line: Shary, you did the best you could. But you can't change this family. Neither can I. From now on I'm just gonna sit back and enjoy the ride.

Line: Nope.

Line: THE HOUSE IS STILL A MESS AND I'M GOING BALD FROM STRESS --

Line: BUT WE'RE HAPPY JUST THE WAY WE ARE!

Line: Thanks for everything!

Line: Kids? Kids?

Line: An occasional hug is all I ask.

Line: Bart's right -- let's none of us have a cow. All that matters is that the fans of the show liked it.

Line: Well, I never thought it would come to this, but I guess we'll have to sell Grandma's Civil War doll.

Line: He is quite a charmer. Your father's certainly taken a shine to him...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Mmm, I don't think he's married, Homer.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, didn't John seem a little... festive to you?

Speaker: Marge
Line: He prefers the company of men!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, listen carefully: John is a ho-mo--

Speaker: Marge
Line: ... sexual.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You're being ridiculous.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm very sorry you feel that way. Because John invited us all out for a drive today, and we're going.

Speaker: Marge
Line: What on earth are you talking about?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, at least come out and say hello.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Come on. You liked John this morning.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, geez Louise, you don't even know what you're worried about anymore. John's a witty, urbane person.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I hope you all saved room, because I made your favorite dessert: store-bought snack cakes! Both kinds!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homie, I can hear you chewing on your pillow. What's wrong?

Speaker: Marge
Line: So if you wore a Hawaiian shirt, it wouldn't be gay?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I don't think there's a problem with Bart. But if there is, it's probably because you're not spending any time with him. Goodnight.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I don't, but I loved hearing it!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, John brought us cactus candy!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Homer, please. You're embarrassing yourself.

Speaker: Marge
Line: What? You never went hunting before, and you're perfectly straight!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Homie, I'm so glad you're safe! Hmmm, you feel softer than before.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Just remember, Bart, convicts aren't "cool." They're bad people.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Someone should really go up there and talk to him.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ho-mer.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, you have nothing to worry about, honey.

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're very proud of you, by the way.

Speaker: Marge
Line: But he's safely locked away!

Speaker: Marge
Line: For life!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Which is impossible!

Speaker: Marge
Line: How can you even think of releasing Sideshow Bob?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, no!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You can't ask God to kill someone!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, that sounds fabulous, Homer. Stores throw the best parties.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You didn't remember that. You just saw it on TV.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Maybe people don't want an eight-year-old babysitter, honey. Parents need to be sure their sitter can handle anything that might happen. That's why they hire teenagers.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Uh, Grampa's not coming...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Actually, Bart, Lisa is going to be in charge tonight.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I know she's young, but Lisa has proven herself mature and dependable.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, we have to run. I'm sure you kids will work things out. Good night!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Make sure he brushes his teeth, Lisa.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Uh, I don't think we should be driving here. The mayor's yelling at us.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, it's so beautiful! This is what I imagine Paris must be like!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm so honored that Springfield has been chosen to host all these upscale chain stores. I guess this makes us "yuppies," huh, Homie?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oooh, Malaria Zone! That's where all the explorers shop.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Isn't that clever? It looks like a Cadillac drove right into the building.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh my God, you walked into the fountain! Get out of the fountain!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Just stand still and I'll get someone!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Young lady, you will never babysit again! I am so disappointed -ointed... - ointed... -ointed...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, I do. I'm just a little concerned about the kids. Maybe I should call.

Speaker: Marge
Line: His arm! Oh, my special little guy, are you okay?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Parades just bring out so many emotions in me: joy, excitement, looking...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Bart, we've bought those before and you always just throw them out the car window on the ride home.

Speaker: Marge
Line: No! No more drinking! I'm tired of looking like the world's worst mother.

Speaker: Marge
Line: All right.

Speaker: Marge
Line: What happened to you, Homer? And what have you done to the car?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I don't think it had broken axles before.

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's funny... I used to be able to go down there.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Why do you have so many bowling balls?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Beer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You're the one the papers have been talking about. That mysterious "Beer Baron" who's been supplying Springfield with alcohol! How have you been getting away with this?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, that's very clever!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, it is. I've known your father since high school and this is the cleverest thing he's ever done. Besides, he's only breaking a silly, two-hundred-year-old law...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Whooh...

Speaker: Marge
Line: What on earth happened down there?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, there's no point in pretending you're making those noises. Your homemade liquor is exploding again.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You've made some money and had the fun of being a wanted criminal. Why not quit now, while you're ahead?

Speaker: Marge
Line: That was a very sweet thing you did for poor Wiggum, but what's going to happen to you?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wait! Wait! You can't do this! All my husband did was violate a law that doesn't make sense. Now, I'll admit car crashes and fist fights have been down recently, but prohibition has cost us our freedom. Our freedom to drink.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Krabappel?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, my goodness.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, Bart's up there!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bills... bills... oo, a free sample of gasoline... a note from Publishers' Clearinghouse saying we're out of the running... oh look, Lisa! You got something.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, this is yours.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm sorry, honey. Here, you can have the junk mail.

Speaker: Marge
Line: ... Bills, bills... Oh a rejection letter from The New Yorker subscription department... Hmm. Who or what is "Santos L. Halper?"

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Bart, you didn't have to do that. Oh!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, where did you get all this stuff?

Speaker: Marge
Line: A frying pan radio. Wow!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, he's so smart!

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's Laddie. Bart says he won him at a church carnival, two towns over.

Speaker: Marge
Line: "Some call it the dog that never sleeps, though it actually does -- while jogging."

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, it's against the house rule... Oh, I guess just this once.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, are you wearing a tie to impress Laddie?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, we wrecked the first dog. We've got to treat this one right. Bart, why don't you take Laddie for another walk.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Besides, he's happy just hanging around the house with Bart.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Maggie, you got oatmeal all over. Homer, would you clean her off?

Speaker: Marge
Line: What's the matter, Bart? Weren't you happy with him?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, if that's what you think is best, let's just go down to the kennel and get Santa's Little Helper back.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, what in the heck are you doing?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, I think it's a great idea.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, I'm sorry!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, you didn't tell me Mr. Burns went broke and lost the nuclear power plant.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You told me about that candy bar you found three times!

Speaker: Marge
Line: They're not going to close the plant, are they?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wow, he went from stinking rich to just plain stinking.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Yeah, he's broke!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, nobody likes a gloater. Right, Homie?

Speaker: Marge
Line: See!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, you do whatever your conscience tells you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You did the right thing, sweetheart.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh my goodness. Kids! Homer! We're late for church! I'm glad I dressed last night.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, the Lord only asks for an hour a week.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hey, calm down. You're wrinkling your church clothes!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Church shouldn't be a chore. It should help you in your daily life.

Speaker: Marge
Line: The dump?

Speaker: Marge
Line: No, no, I don't feel like going to a trash pile today.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's crazy!

Speaker: Marge
Line: ...sermons about "constancy" and "prudissitude" are all very well and good, but the church could be doing so much more to reach out to people.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well... okay. I will volunteer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: All done! I swept the aisles and put all the collection plates in the dishwasher. Oh, and you wouldn't believe how many dead pigeons there were in the organ.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wow.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Reverend, I hate to say this, but it sounded like that poor man was reaching out to you. I'm not sure your advice was all that helpful.

Speaker: Marge
Line: But you can't let a few bad experiences sour you on helping people!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Me?

Speaker: Marge
Line: No, I... I... Wait, I can't... I-- Hello...?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, well, this is... um... the, uh... the Listen Lady!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay, uh, why don't you start from the top?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, that's ridiculous, Moe. You've got lots to live for.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I don't know... guilt?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, I think volunteering is great. Deep down it makes you feel --

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer! Will you get that crazy box off the dinner table? It came from the dump.

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's ridiculous. Nobody is watching us right now.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Lenny, I'm sure he'll like your wife no matter what she looks like.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh. Well, it's time to start telling the truth. Now, when I have to tell my husband the truth, I cook him a big delicious dinner. By the time he's done eating, he's too full and tired to care what I have to say.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Please, one at a time, one at a time! Now, who has the most urgent problem?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Come right this way, Mel. I... Tim, hold my calls.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hello, Listen Lady.

Speaker: Marge
Line: We all need a little time to ourselves, Helen. Just give him a day or two and I'm sure he'll be back to his old dynamic self.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You've just got to accept it. Your GameBoy is gone. It's at the bottom of the ocean.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hello. Listen Lady.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, Ned, you don't have to stand for that. You just march right up to those youngsters and tell them to vamoose.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hello. Listen Lady.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Now, Ned, troubled boys need rules and discipline. They crave it! You just lay down the law.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, all right, let me talk to them. Put me on with the lead boy.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hmmm. Oh well.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, good morning, Maude.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Of course he did.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh my God... Ned!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Reverend, I gave Ned Flanders some bad advice. Now he could be in real trouble.

Speaker: Marge
Line: No, he's disappeared. Oh, I'm in way over my head. I mean, where do the helpers turn when they need help?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Sorry.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ned! Where are you?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Donny's discount gas!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Donny!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Did you see a man being chased by some young hooligans?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Swipe at the dominant male! C'mon, Ned, knock that monkey down!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You've got to get him out of there!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Thank heavens!

Speaker: Marge
Line: They started it!

Speaker: Marge
Line: "MARGE" is already taken? Oh, how about "MARJORIE"?

Speaker: Marge
Line: How about..."MITZI"?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hmmm... "NITZI"...

Speaker: Marge
Line: I only have five lobsters. Are you sure he's not bringing anyone with him?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Calm down, Homer. Calm down. Answer the door.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hello.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, why aren't you at work?

Speaker: Marge
Line: You're afraid to go to work because Frank Grimes will be there, aren't you?

Speaker: Marge
Line: You'll have to face him sometime. And when you do, I'm sure he'll be just as anxious to make up as you are.

Speaker: Marge
Line: He doesn't hate you. He just feels insecure because you're getting through life so easily and it's been so difficult for him.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, maybe... but I'll bet he would be less crazy if you were just a little more... professional in your work.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Just a little more... Then he won't have any reason to resent you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I wouldn't bother him, honey. He's making some kind of model for a contest. He says it's really high-tech stuff that we wouldn't understand.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hello, dear. How was work at the plant?

Speaker: Marge
Line: REMEMBER ME? MY NAME IS MARGE! / THE TV MOM WHOSE HAIR IS LARGE!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ghost? What ghost?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I said we were having a special guest tonight -- Mr. Tim Conway.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know Homer, we've all been busy as beavers preparing for our very own show.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Yes! And it might look something like this...

Speaker: Marge
Line: I know. And I made your favorite --

Speaker: Marge
Line: Stakes!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart!

Speaker: Marge
Line: In a minute, Homie. I have to get the door.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Inflation, trade deficit, horrible war atrocities... how are we supposed to do our big musical number with so many problems in the world?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Christian love?

Speaker: Marge
Line: But don't you want to end world famine?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Or save the endangered Alaskan salmon?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, if you won't think of society's ills...

Speaker: Marge
Line: At least think of our dentist bills!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, it's time to say "good night."

Speaker: Marge
Line: He's just kidding. We'd like to thank FOX, and the good people at Budget Lodge.

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're like this all the time!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I certainly hope so! That's better.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Now, about your punishment, young man.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I tell you, Chief, I just don't know what we're going to do with him.

Speaker: Marge
Line: No! No drugs. Bart just needs a little discipline.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know, maybe Chief Wiggum is right. Military school is a good idea.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, it certainly was nice of you to accept Bart in the middle of the semester.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, he sure sucked the fun out of that poem.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, no! This place is just a jail for children.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, if you ever want to quit and come home, I'll be here in half a jiff.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, honey... I heard you the first time.

Speaker: Marge
Line: ...and don't worry, sweetie, it's very common to be homesick when you're so far away from the people who love you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: "YOU ARE MY SUNSHINE, MY ONLY SUNSHINE / YOU MAKE ME HAPPY, WHEN SKIES ARE GRAY / YOU'LL NEVER KNOW, DEAR / HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU / SO DON'T TAKE MY SUNSHINE AWAY..."

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, he's got more confidence!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I don't want you driving around in a car you built yourself.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Sorry, sorry.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Why not?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Homer. Of course you'll have a bad impression of New York if you only focus on the pimps and the CHUDs.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Great! We're all going to New York!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wake up, everyone. We're almost there.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer! Homer, those legs belong to the man behind you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wow! I feel like such a nobody.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's wall-to-wall landmarks -- the Williamsburg Bridge! Fourth Avenue! Governor's Island!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, you're scaring the children.

Speaker: Marge
Line: The bus station is just one of the sights we came to see. We'll meet you in Central Park at five o'clock.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wow, Governor's Island looks so insignificant from up here.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm so glad we took the subway. "Laser Wart Removal". Wow, the future is here!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Are we still in Little Italy?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Only in New York!

Speaker: Marge
Line: No. No Lisa, they're just... sleeping. Upside down. And inside out.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, no fireworks! Put that back!

Speaker: Marge
Line: If only I didn't already have a pair of shoes.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Stay where I can see you, honey...

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know, when I was a girl, I always dreamed of being in a Broadway audience.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You better start saving now. It's very expensive.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I hope your father had as much fun as we did.

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're not jumping, Homer.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart? Why are you doing that?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Uh huh, that explains the flags. What about the dog food?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Let's bake him a cake.

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's not a funny story.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Not to us you're not. I mean, how would you feel if you suddenly found out Ned Flanders was an impostor?

Speaker: Marge
Line: My next-door neighbor? Religious guy?

Speaker: Marge
Line: No I don't! What I mean is, to me you're just a stranger pretending to be something he's not.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm sorry, but that's just how I feel.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'd sure hate to get a dozen crapweeds for Valentine's Day. I'd rather have candy.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Good morning, Agnes. How's your new son working out?

Speaker: Marge
Line: And have ten items or less.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, now be fair, Edna. I liked Armin Tamzarian too, but he was at least as big a weenie as Sgt. Skinner.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Did you ever tell him that?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I came up with the idea.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Because the streets of Capitol City are no place for three unescorted ladies.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Because we couldn't find Grampa to sit for them.

Speaker: Marge
Line: MOVIES JOHN TRAVOLTA MADE...

Speaker: Marge
Line: THOSE WERE THE DAYS.

Speaker: Marge
Line: AND YOU KNEW WHERE YOU WERE THEN...

Speaker: Marge
Line: COMING OUT OF MY EIGHT-TRACK...

Speaker: Marge
Line: MICHAEL JACKSON STILL WAS BLACK...

Speaker: Marge
Line: THOSE WERE THE DAYS.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, honey, I can't right now. Bart's gonna be late!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ooh, there's the bus. Goodbye, sweetheart!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hi honey! How was your first day of school? Honey?

Speaker: Marge
Line: IT'S A SHAME WHAT SCHOOL CAN DO.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I can't get the baby to burp. Could you try for a while?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Sure, honey. Bart had just completed his first day at school. And Bart just...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Sorry, Lisa. It's just how the story goes. No matter what Bart tried, he just couldn't fit in at school.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, would you like to read a book?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Would you like to color something?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I want you to look at this drawing Bart did.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer stop! Would you please look at the drawing?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I think we're going to have to get Bart some help.

Speaker: Marge
Line: With nowhere else to turn, we went to see the school psychologist...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart's gay?

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's wonderful! But still, can't you do anything for Bart?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Look, I knew private school would be expensive but I was hoping we could get a scholarship of some sort.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Come on, honey. I guess this is a world you'll never know.

Speaker: Marge
Line: And sometimes I feel so smothered by this family I just want to scream till my lungs explode! Uh... I'll go start dinner now.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, Grampa, as long as you're here, we were telling a story that took place when Bart was five and Lisa was three.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Yeeesss. Well, as if our troubles weren't bad enough, Springfield was going through an unseasonable heat wave...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, have you seen the frozen peas?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Uhh... you keep 'em. Now listen. If we can't afford private school, maybe there's some other way to encourage Lisa. Umm, an art class... ballet lessons... they have some fun things you could do at the Museum on Saturday...

Speaker: Marge
Line: I guess it doesn't matter. All these things cost money and we just don't have it. Unless...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, there's that two hundred dollars we've been saving for the new air conditioner.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I cannot believe this. I'm trying to give our daughter a head start in life and you aren't helping a bit.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Balzac!

Speaker: Marge
Line: But Balzac is the name--

Speaker: Marge
Line: Please, just promise you won't buy an air conditioner till we've figured out a way to help Lisa.

Speaker: Marge
Line: And so, just as things looked their worst...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Grampa, what are you talking about?

Speaker: Marge
Line: As I was saying, things couldn't be worse for Lisa or Bart...

Speaker: Marge
Line: What "origin"? We get 'em for a dollar ninety-five down at the Safeway.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know, Homer... I think we have some money in the air conditioner account again, hmmm?

Speaker: Marge
Line: You're a good father.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, you know how unpredictable the French are. One minute they're kissing a woman's hand, the next they're chopping off her head. What if they start a war?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homie, is that you?

Speaker: Marge
Line: That sounds beautiful, Ned. And let me just say, my family and I share your vision for a better NOW!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Friends with mutants, right.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, no!

Speaker: Marge
Line: What's going on down there? What's all this mist?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, well, he may be a horrible freak, but he's still my son. I'm sure we'll grow to accept him in time.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, stop that!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ohh, you want more syrup, honey?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Mm! Shoo! Shoo, fly!

Speaker: Marge
Line: They're like this every rainy day.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, what are you doing?

Speaker: Marge
Line: How horrible.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Let's come to our senses, everyone. This witch hunt is turning into a circus.

Speaker: Marge
Line: This is crazy! I'm not a witch!

Speaker: Marge
Line: What?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's right, I'm a witch! And I'm the one who withered your livestock, soured your sheeps' milk and made your shirts itchy.

Speaker: Marge
Line: No, that was gophers.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Not all of them...

Speaker: Marge
Line: And this is for pushing me off the cliff.

Speaker: Marge
Line: As for the rest of you...

Speaker: Marge
Line: What a day! They found out I was a witch so I had to leave my family.

Speaker: Marge
Line: His name is Homer.

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're here to eat your kids.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Candied apple!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I just wish we hadn't filled up on all those kids before we got to the Flanders'.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's hard to believe this used to be an internment camp.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer. We gotta get out of here.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh my God, Homer! They're right next door!

Speaker: Marge
Line: What do you recommend?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wouldn't we all suffocate?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, we need something to protect this family.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I don't want guns in my house! Don't you remember when Maggie shot Mr. Burns?

Speaker: Marge
Line: No! No one's using this gun. The TV said, you're 58 per cent more likely to shoot a family member than an intruder.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm sorry, Homer. No weapons.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, you can't join up with these gun nuts.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Does anyone know where all my dinner plates went?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I told you this morning, no guns at the dinner table.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's the same table!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I think you'd agree that I've put up with a lot in this marriage.

Speaker: Marge
Line: But this is the first time since we've been married that I've actually feared for our lives. So I'm asking you, if you really care about me and the children, please, please get rid of the gun.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm a lucky woman.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart!

Speaker: Marge

Line: Well, let's count that anyway.

Line: It's a natural process that women of a certain age go through.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Selma, I never realized you wanted a child so badly.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Don't cry, sweetie. Everything's gonna be all right.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wait till the Drambuie and sleeping pills kick in.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Go, go, go!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, if you do this one small favor, it could transform Selma's life.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay, don't do it for her--

Speaker: Marge
Line: Do it for me.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Thank you, Mr. Simpson.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, no stop! You're thinking of Buckingham Palace!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Mind your manners, Lisa.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Selma, she's beautiful!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, of all the sneaky, dishonest things you've ever done, playing Selma's husband was by far the sweetest.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay, one quick snuggle.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hold still, Homie.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Just think about the day you found that Junior Mint in your bellybutton.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Plus, we get free apple, orange and grapefruit juice!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Is there anything more fun than a nice Sunday drive?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hey, hey, it's Krusty the clown! What do you say, Krusty?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Always nice to see him.

Speaker: Marge
Line: He's cleaning out the garage. I can picture it now...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homie!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, thank God! He's alive!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Honey... your near-fatal boo boo today really scared me. What would the kids and I do if something happened to you?

Speaker: Marge
Line: You keep almost dying. Just look at our vacation photos.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homie, if you die, I'm gonna have three kids to take care of. I want you to buy some life insurance. Please?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I know, I just wan--

Speaker: Marge
Line: You don't smoke!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm not gonna worry just because Homer doesn't have insurance. A lot of people don't!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, this is only based on a story. A true story!

Speaker: Marge
Line: We need to start saving!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Go easy on that -- it's gotta last 'til you're five.

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's right. It's much less expensive than the leading clown-based cereal. You just have to assemble it yourself.

Speaker: Marge
Line: We saved fifty cents on that purchase!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, we're just saving for... a very rainy day.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, I just think we should be building a nest egg.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I have a book from the library with the same information!

Speaker: Marge
Line: No more directory assistance! It's not free!

Speaker: Marge
Line: No more oriental mustard!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Can you help me unload this soup from the car? There was a sale, so I bought four hundred cans.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh Honey, I know it's not easy, but we've got to put money away.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Don't you think you've had enough "fun?"

Speaker: Marge
Line: Last year, you spent five thousand dollars on donuts, two thousand on scalp massages, five hundred on body glitter--

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh please. From what I hear, you waltz in there at 10:30, take a nap on the toilet, then sit around "Google"-ing your own name until lunch.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You shouted it while we were making love! Now look here, Mister. I pay the bills, I do the budget, and I'm in charge of the money.

Speaker: Marge
Line: My scrimpings!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Did you spend our savings on a motor home?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well I hope you enjoy it, your majesty -- 'cause I'm not speaking to you!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Kids, come back in the house!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I melted string cheese over some corn chips!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'll let you sass me!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You can wear swimsuits instead of underwear!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: What are all these recreational vehicles doing here?

Speaker: Marge
Line: This is a house!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I know another place you can go -- to sleep!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Can't turn off the power, eh?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lights out, weirdoes!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You don't belong on the lawn. You belong in your bed with your wife!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, you're not perfect either!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You hide food in my hair... you think brushing your teeth is foreplay...

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'll have you know I could have married Sideshow Mel!

Speaker: Marge
Line: And I'm so sick of that story about finding an onion ring in your French fries. It was twenty years ago!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Captain, wait! I have something here that might change your mind!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You don't take anything seriously. Not even your bankruptcy hearing!

Speaker: Marge
Line: "Dear Mom and Dad: We don't want you guys to split up, so we're driving the RV back to the dealer." We've got to stop them.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh my God, there they are!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, I've lost them! I can't see past all the SUVs!

Speaker: Marge
Line: We'll stop fighting, we promise!

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're not quite there yet, but we've opened up a dialogue!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, come here!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Now pull over!

Speaker: Marge
Line: My kids are on your boat -- turn back!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Three hundred cans of Budget Club mushroom soup! If you have some noodles and tuna fish, you could make a casserole that's small on price, but big on flavor.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, if he thinks he's getting a corner piece, forget it.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hey, it's only money. And it did make a cool splash.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Which came first, turkey the bird or Turkey the you guys?

Speaker: Marge
Line: If you don't want to say it, just think it.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know, we should visit Shelbyville more often. They have a store that just sells shoes. I feel like I'm in Paris!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Let's see. There's "Equus" starring Sideshow Mel... "The Three Dollar Bills in 'Gay, Gay, Gay!'"... ooh, "Song Of Shelbyville"!

Speaker: Marge
Line: This is the worst crisis the Springfield Cultural Activities Board has ever faced.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Those Shelbyvillians are maligning us all. I've never heard such mean-spirited hate-hoots.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Why do you come to these meetings?

Speaker: Marge
Line: There must be something else. Think Marge, think. Culture... vulture... birds of prey... pray in a church... the father, son and Holy Ghost... ghosts are scary, scary rhymes with Gehry! That's it -- Architect Frank Gehry! He could build us a concert hall like he did in Los Angeles.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Then it's agreed! We ask Frank Gehry to build us a concert hall!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Dear Mr. Gehry: Would you please build a concert hall for our town? We may not be the biggest city, or the prettiest, but we were the first city in America to abandon the metric system!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I wrote that letter.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, aren't you?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm so excited. It's like giving birth to a child of steel and iron.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Don't leave now! The next piece is an atonal medley by Philip Glass!

Speaker: Marge
Line: He's turned it into a prison!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ooh, a Tiffany's box! And the thing inside is from Tiffany's! Homie, you've never done this before. How'd you afford it?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Haven't you seen what happens to people who rat in prison movies?

Speaker: Marge
Line: The prison snitch is killed! And that could be you! Because you're the prison snitch!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer! Homer, where are you?

Speaker: Marge
Line: As President of the cultural board I was given a key to the concert hall.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, you must be Michael's dad!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I want you to look into the faces of those poor men -- each one is a life you made worse with your ratting.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, Homie...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Governor, I think the only fair solution is to pardon all these thugs and murderers.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Kids, come down for your prom photo!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oooh. Smile!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh it's so great. We can do anything now that scientists have invented magic. I'm so proud of you. Lisa, graduating two years early, and Bart... graduating.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, we're separated now. You can't just walk in without knocking.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, just settle down. We just got a postcard from Maggie.

Speaker: Marge
Line: She's really enjoying Alaska.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, your date's here!

Speaker: Marge
Line: When I was a kid we didn't show our affection by head-butting.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, I am so glad you think so.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Kids... I want you to know I've started seeing someone. He's from Springfield, I think you know him...

Speaker: Marge
Line: The one what?

Speaker: Marge
Line: You mean get beaten up by him?

Speaker: Marge
Line: And I'll admit, it is kinda romantic under the sea.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, do something about this leak!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know Homer, I let a lot of things slide, but when you can't keep a roof over your family's head, you're just not much of a father.

Speaker: Marge
Line: That teddy bear survived three safety recalls, but it couldn't survive you!

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's raining inside!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer! I woke up to find an owl eating a mouse on the pillow next to me.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It means you have to fix the roof!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Knockers on route 98.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm psychic. Look, I don't know if I want a roofer who hangs out in bars.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, he better high-five our roof!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Come on, kids! We're gonna visit Grampa. Then we're gonna take the dog to the V-E-T...

Speaker: Marge
Line: ...then take Bart to get C-I-R-C-U-M-C-I-S-E-D.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'll tell you what it means when it's over.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay kids, we only have time for a quick visit to Grampa, so as soon as he feels loved, we're outta there.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, he must smell leftovers.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, he does seem happy here...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You're drooling on my Goodwill pile!

Speaker: Marge
Line: And why is the hole in the roof even bigger?

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's after six -- he's not coming back. He's a lousy roofer and a flake!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I don't want to hear any more about Ray. Tomorrow morning you buy some shingles and fix that roof yourself.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You're not married to Ray!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Yeah, I bet the old people will be acting like young people, like in those cell phone ads everyone hates.

Speaker: Marge
Line: He's become one of them!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hey boy, want a treat?

Speaker: Marge
Line: We better get you home. Come on, Lisa.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Geez Louise...

Speaker: Marge
Line: How you feeling, sweetie?

Speaker: Marge
Line: What are you doing? Why aren't you fixing the roof?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm so sick of hearing about that stupid, unreliable Ray! Who, by the way, I've never even met!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, how did you think I'd feel when I saw that?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, come down for dinner.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ray's not coming!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I know where Ray is.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Sweetheart, your friend Ray is in your head.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You have to understand -- Ray doesn't exist.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, no one has ever seen Ray but you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I called that bosom bar. The bartender said you were there alone.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Electro-shock?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I see Ray too.

Speaker: Marge
Line: When did I agree to that?

Speaker: Marge
Line: You didn't validate my parking.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Wait, there's still one last thing that doesn't make sense. Why did you start fixing our roof and then just disappear?

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's right -- you're all crooks!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, I spent all afternoon stuffing tuna fish into that steak. Have some.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, so I've been replaced by a machine?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well until that day, I'm still Bart's mother, and I don't like him stuffing himself with junk.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, fine.

Speaker: Marge
Line: His liver looks healthy.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Doctor, you're a pediatrician!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I talked to Dr. Hibbert today. He gave me a list of heart-smart foods.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Cottage cheese!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Aw honey, please take this seriously. When people used to ask me how you were doing, I said "at least he's got his health." Now you've got nothing! Nothing! For me, please try a healthy vegetable.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay, now we know you're allergic to cauliflower. But I made a special platter of vegetables that are good for you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's graffiti you can eatie!

Speaker: Marge
Line: They're not kidnappers! They're professionally trained child-snatchers, who are taking you to a maximum-security fat camp.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Forty-seven?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Don't you mean "tough love?"

Speaker: Marge
Line: Jimminy Kimmel! Look how much they're charging for Bart's treatment!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I already use crayons for lipstick, and fireplace soot for eyeliner.

Speaker: Marge
Line: This fat camp can save Bart's life -- we have to find a way to pay for it. Homer, maybe you could ask Mr. Burns for a raise.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, what are you doing here?

Speaker: Marge
Line: But... you're still fat!

Speaker: Marge
Line: To give these Germans das boot? Jawohl!

Speaker: Marge
Line: No you didn't.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I was hoping we'd miss the three o'clock hold-up. I don't know what to do for dinner now.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Vegetables, you've been promoted from side dish to entrée.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, don't use that word... Oh crap.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Don't worry about the competition, sweetie. Whenever I enter a contest I tell myself I'm going to win because, sometimes, if you believe hard enough, God cuts you a break. After all, he works for us. Our prayers pay his salary.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, that sounds like a fancier version of the song you're going to sing!

Speaker: Marge
Line: But your song said you liked Springfield.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Sweetie, tonight you were perfect...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homie, I'm worried you're turning into some kind of super koo-koo stage mother.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, you wanna go to the video arcade?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Actually, I think your father's still upset about the way things went down.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hey, kids! I scream, you scream, we all scream for...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Haircuts!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You have?! That's so nice!

Speaker: Marge
Line: A kids' barbershop? But they don't have my templates.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh. I see. Well, good luck getting to your precious mall barber, 'cause I'm not driving you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I guess I'll just cut my own hair.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Sweetie, don't worry. God wouldn't spring the Rapture on us unannounced. He'd send us signs, like, I don't know, all the dogs getting on a spaceship and leaving.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ooh, I could be the Rachel to your Jacob.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Here's a pretty little wig for Lisa, and a handsome toupee for Bart!

Speaker: Marge
Line: So, you still think I'm crazy for saving all your hair trimmings?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay then. Let's get the rest of this hair back in the freezer.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, you didn't touch your second dinner tonight. And you're reading books! Word books! What's going on?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Three million, one hundred and--

Speaker: Marge
Line: May eighteenth? That's one week from today!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, I'm glad you're getting exercise, I just wish it wasn't crazy exercise.

Speaker: Marge
Line: The stars are falling to the earth!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Just as you predicted.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa's going! We're all going!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm so proud of you, Homie!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homie... I'd better start dinner.

Speaker: Marge
Line: We're not going anywhere, except to bed!

Speaker: Marge
Line: You couldn't predict six o'clock at five thirty! Now good night!

Speaker: Marge
Line: The worst part is I'll never see my Homie again!

Speaker: Marge
Line: The Warren Harding Through-hole never seemed so long.

Speaker: Marge
Line: But we don't have a sitter for Maggie.

Speaker: Marge
Line: A TV shark is not a babysitter!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Honey, you can be anything you want to be.

Speaker: Marge
Line: What language is this? Gibby-Gabby?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, don't make fun of grad students -- they just made a terrible life choice.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ned, let me give you a little something for babysitting.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You've got a big house, Ned. If you need extra money, why don't you rent out a room?

Speaker: Marge
Line: What are you two doing?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart! Turn away from that screen and look out the window!

Speaker: Marge
Line: It's happening in Ned's house! Why would he allow that?

Speaker: Marge
Line: C'mon. You tell him right now. Ned, Homer has something to tell you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You know what I mean.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, Homer, you've driven away the best neighbor a family could ever want. But at least we have a chance to start fresh -- so let's be on our best behavior, okay?

Speaker: Marge
Line: That's coming from next door!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, get your things. You're leaving with me!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, I love you. But sometimes I don't love your choices. Now we have to find another school for you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, this could be a good new school... Oakwood Academy! Huh?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Think of the leg up you'd have!

Speaker: Marge
Line: What if there's a fire?

Speaker: Marge
Line: How 'bout this one -- St. Jerome's Catholic School?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bart, I'm glad you had fun, but I wouldn't get too into that Catholic church. With all the sitting and standing and kneeling, it's like Simon Says without a winner!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Don't you touch bead one! Homer, maybe we should be concerned. Catholics can be a peculiar bunch -- no birth control, no meat on Friday...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Let's just change the subject. Bart, would you like to say grace?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, you've been out all night! And you look like you've accepted someone as your personal something. Were you at that Catholic Church?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I knew they'd try to convert you! That's what they do! Well I'm not having another twelve kids.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Forget it! And you know, I went to a Catholic wedding once. The incense ruined my pantsuit!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, Homer and Bart are well, they're under the weather.

Speaker: Marge
Line: All right! I admit it -- they're both at the Catholic Church! Reverend, what should I do?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I guess it's good that they're taking an interest in spirituality.

Speaker: Marge
Line: where's Homer and Bart?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I wish my family was with me.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well then, I'd like to speak with Jesus.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Noooo!!!

Speaker: Marge
Line: First Communion?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, you're physically an adult, and what you do in the privacy of your own soul is your business. But I didn't change Bart's diapers for five years to see him become a Catholic.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Let's go!

Speaker: Marge
Line: They weren't following us.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I just don't think your father's the right person to pick out a religion for you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hello, Homer.

Speaker: Marge
Line: It wasn't a fair fight! Your church suckered him in with gory stories, just like we were suckered into getting Cinemax.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, I'm gonna show Bart that Protestants can be hip too. How do you like those croutons?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Now Bart, isn't this the kind of religion you'd like to be a part of for all eternity?

Speaker: Marge
Line: What's wrong, Bart? You love youth culture!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh Bart, I knew one of these dumb things would work!

Speaker: Marge
Line: My hive! My trademark hive!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Why would we want to go to Santa's Village? It's August.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, before I take the kids, I want you to swear you're not up to something.

Speaker: Marge
Line: And I'd also like to know why your hand is in that cast.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Fros-ty! Where's your magic top hat?

Speaker: Marge
Line: My Christmas present to myself this year was leaving that place early.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Look, I know this wasn't the greatest outing, but your father meant well, so don't let him know that we didn't .

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Is this a snuggle film?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: How could you allow this, in the room where we... do puzzles?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: All right.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Away from you.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I don't know.

Speaker: Marge
Line: You are.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Bye Bart! I love you, Lisa! Sleep tight, Maggie! Today's the last day you can eat the yogurt in the fridge!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Can he swim?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I guess I'd better tell them I'm coming home.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm at a rest stop south of Springfield. I know, you're sorry now. Then you'll buy me some Kwik-E-Mart flowers, maybe a box of candy where half the pieces mysteriously have "testing bites," and a week later you'll be back to your old thoughtless self.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I love you too...

Speaker: Marge
Line: Hold on, I'll be off in a minute.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Listen, buster. I had to buy a club soda I didn't want to get change for this phone!

Speaker: Marge
Line: An oogli-boogli!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'll call you back!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well what if by harming a manatee you could save two manatees? But before you answer, consider this: the manatee you'd have to harm is pregnant.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I think the worst part was when I realized that Homer lied to me.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Exactly!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Maybe you could just put a hat on him and say it's a trick.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Huh.

Speaker: Marge
Line: And treated like I deserve.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay, water monsters. Be friendly. But not too friendly.

Speaker: Marge
Line: What do I do?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Okay. Uh... you know, up close you're kinda cute.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Aw, you're a good thing. I know it. Let me clean out your ears.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I've bonded with him!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Where is he taking me?

Speaker: Marge
Line: I've got my groove back!

Speaker: Marge
Line: I can't believe how many manatees we saved today.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Ooo.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homie, I accept your apology.

Speaker: Marge
Line: But I'm not coming back yet.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I've found a place where I'm needed.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm sorry, Homie. I just can't find it in my heart to come back right now.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, my sweet, sweet Homie! You sacrificed yourself for the manatees.

Speaker: Marge
Line: I'm gonna take you home and fix you up, 'cause you're the real endangered species... a devoted husband.

Speaker: Marge
Line: And I always will.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Don't you have to be back at work?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer! Do something about the noise!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Well, they just can't start building in our neighborhood without asking us. What ever happened to "please" and "thank you"?

Speaker: Marge
Line: We have to stop all this construction. The noise is jiggling my grapes to the bottom of the Jell-o.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Instead of a stamp museum we'll be next door to a graveyard?!

Speaker: Marge
Line: This is a little too spooky for me. I don't even like watching "The Count" on Sesame Street.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Go back to your own country!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh sure you can, sweetie. Just don't make a habit of it.

Speaker: Marge
Line: So that's why I've been smelling margaritas at three a.m.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, honey. I know last night was tough, but all our kids sleep by themselves. We don't even hear Maggie cry at night anymore!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Oh, wait a minute. There's no batteries in this thing.

Speaker: Marge
Line: Tonight I want you to really try to sleep in your own bed, because... Homer, stop that!

Speaker: Marge
Line: NOOOO!

Speaker: Marge
Line: Homer, can you help me out here?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Isn't this Lenny's house?

Speaker: Marge
Line: Lisa, do you really want to watch this?

Speaker: Marge

Line: I invited him to stay with us for a few days. His career is ruined, and I was afraid he might commit you-know-what-icide.

Line: You'll have to excuse him -- he's been watching a lot of Fox News.

Line: We have to take in Mr. Brockman -- he wouldn't be in this mess if you hadn't dumped coffee on his lap.

Line: Homer, you smell like Chicago. Did you fly there on a commercial airline?

Line: Wow. Is it much different from a normal plane?

Line: This is Colby Krause. I hired him to help you improve your life. He'll get you back on a private plane in no time!

Line: We're all so proud of you, sweetie.

Line: Find out if he has a wife! We could double date!

Line: So, how was your first day at your new job?

Line: Hello?

Line: It's bad news, isn't it? I should never get my hopes up. Nothing ever works out for us.

Line: Look at this business center -- fax, Wi-Fi, teleconferencing capabilities... I'm gonna remember this day for the rest of my life!

Line: Sweetheart, what do you mean?

Line: Homie, what are you doing? You don't know how to fly!

Line: There's only one man who could help us now.

Line: It's Marge Simpson. I need you to coach like you've never coached before.

Line: Now you listen here, Bub. We paid you all the savings we had in the world. You could at least tell my husband something encouraging.

Line: Homer, you did it! You landed a jet!

Line: I understand, Homie.

Line: We left her last week and she didn't make it home for dinner!

Line: Well, where should we go for brunch?

Line: Oh my God! Oh my God! Quick, everyone put on their long faces!

Line: Homer, can't we please be alone? It's our anniversary.

Line: I couldn't agree more, Julia.

Line: I'm so tense, I can't enjoy Count Almaviva serenading the intended bride of Dr. Bartolo. I just can't.

Line: You have to be there -- you miss way too many precious moments in the children's lives.

Line: That old man over there isn't even making a transaction. He just wants someone to talk to!

Line: All right, this time I'm going. I'm really going to visit a bank robber. A man who held a gun on me. Going to see him in prison, where guards will frisk me, paw through my purse, and... Oooh, there's apple picking just up the road!

Line: I really shouldn't show up without an apple pie for Dwight. In fact, I really shouldn't show up without an apple pie for everyone at the prison.

Line: So you're good at noticing dress colors, but not the eyes that make your dinner!

Line: What are you hiding from me? Is it chocolate?

Line: I appreciate you trying to become more attractive for me. But the truth is... I'm way too successful for you now. I'm gettin' me a trophy husband!

Line: Okay.

Line: The doctor called me about all the crazy surgeries you wanted. And I said no. But I did have him unstaple your stomach and turn you back into the sweet man I love.

Line: Well, maybe I could. But every time I look at you, I see the same adorable boy I fell in love with.

Line: Ooo, Opal!

Line: Here's a message for you: Ba-doop, ba-doop, ba-doop!

Line: I think I'll speed through the cheering.

Line: I've gotten so much accomplished: I saved "Lost", watched all of "Rome" in a day, and got through "Two and a Half Men" in two and a half minutes. Then I ran out of space and had to choose between "Sophie's Choice" and "Schindler's List."

Line: Keith Olbermann?!

Line: Of course.

Line: I'm honoring America's advertisers. Then we're going to buy some toothpaste, lease a new car, and vote "yes" on Prop Eighty-Seven.

Line: Impossible! Their commercial featured a talking frog.

Line: Yowza!

Line: That's odd -- there doesn't seem to be anyone here.

Line: Bart, I know this is nuts, but try to look sad.

Line: Homer, your behavior is heinous.

Line: Speaking of disasters, have you seen this? Springfield Dodge bought too much inventory, and they've only got one weekend to get rid of all the '07s!

Line: Lisa, I'm sure this Wiggum-arole will blow over -- you have to have faith in the wisdom of the average voter.

Line: No!!! That's my memory box!

Line: Hey, parents are allowed to keep some secrets.

Line: There is a part of our past that we haven't told you kids about. A turbulent part.

Line: But our happiness was about to unravel just like Kevin Costner's career: because of the postman.

Line: Anyway, I was growing to admire my professor more and more...

Line: Homer's perfect for me! Just look at this note: "I miss you." Aww...

Line: Whatever, Homer and I had the wrenching task of dividing up a shared life...

Line: Unfortunately, as I later learned, that wasn't heroin. It was insulin.

Line: Homer really did need those injections.

Line: Homer, stop!

Line: You don't have to tell the kids everything!

Line: Well that professor did teach me one good lesson -- Homie is where my heart is.

Line: I can't wait to see my Valentine's Day surprise!

Line: A carnival? What's so romantic about this?

Line: This is a terrible Valentine's Day.

Line: Romeo and Juliet? Arthur and Guinevere? Brangelina?

Line: So that's the end of the story, huh?

Line: All right! This is a story of two dogs with a love so strong, no hose could separate them. I call it Shady and the Vamp...

Line: Kids, knock it off. I'm uncomfortable driving your father's car as it is.

Line: What the?

Line: Stop it! Stop it!

Line: Honey, this is how I save money on ketchup and mustard.

Line: No, I'm kind of embarrassed about it.

Line: Did you just unlock the car from here?

Line: Come and get me, you syrupy stack of man-cakes.

Line: Jeez Louise. Are you okay?

Line: It's your new diet!

Line: Your lack of bedroom pizzazz last night started me worrying. So I hired this nutritionist, Betsy Bidwell.

Line: This is my husband...

Line: I think he's been Sneakering on his diet.

Line: Zack, you're not trying to help our marriage, you're trying to split us up! I'd rather have a chubby hubby than a sexy exy!

Line: Aw Marge, if there was a reality show called "Fat Guys Who Really Love Their Wives", not only would it be an enormous ratings success, but I'd be the first one on it.

Line: A ballet academy here in Springfield?! Move over, Europe!

Line: There were so many things I wanted to do in life that I never got a chance to do: doctor , safecracker , stethoscope sales lady ... none came to pass. But the thing I really wanted to be, ever since I was little, was a ballerina!
